# Create model
model = DecisionTreeRegressor(max_leaf_nodes=800, random_state=1)
# Set the features
features = ['YEARS', 'Rec_Rank', 'porpag', 'dporpag', 'FT_per', 'bpm', 'AST_per', 'usg', 'TP_per', 'adjoe', 'adrtg', 'stl_per', 'pts']
   
# Set target to be advanced VORP
y = data.ADVANCED_VORP
# Create X
X = data[features]
    
# Split data into training and validation
train_X, val_X, train_y, val_y = train_test_split(X, y, random_state=1)

# Fit model to the data
model.fit(train_X, train_y)

# Create validation predictions for each year
val_preds = model.predict(val_X)
val_mae = mean_absolute_error(val_preds, val_y)
print(" Validation MAE: {:,.5f}".format(val_mae))

model.get_params()

# Background

Using College Statistics to predict an NBA career is a goal of many avid NBA fans, reporters, teams, and analysts. College players are often described as "boom or bust", meaning they have a chance of becoming a superstar while simultaneously having a chance of failing to meet any expectations.

I plan on using College Statistics from Bart Torvik to form a model on all American D1 College Players who have been drafted into the NBA.
Additionally, I used https://github.com/vishaalagartha/basketball_reference_scraper to scrape data from Basketball Reference for each draft class. I used VORP, a statistic that essentially measures how much a player contributes to his team's wins by using plus/minus stats.
